text:
| **This article has multiple issues.** Please help **improve it** or discuss these issues on the **talk page**. _(Learn how and when to remove these messages)_ | | This article needs to be **updated**. Please help update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information. _( January 2021)_  
---|---  
| This article **needs additional citations forverification**. Please help
improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced
material may be challenged and removed.  
_Find sources:_ "Economy of Algeria" – news **·** newspapers **·** books **·**
scholar **·** JSTOR _( January 2021)__(Learn how and when to remove this

---|---  
  
_(Learn how and when to remove this message)_  
  
Algerian exports in 2006 View of the oil port of Béjaïa.

The **economy of Algeria** deals with Algeria's current and structural
economic situation. Currently, Algeria has a mixed economy. Since independence
in 1962, Algeria has launched major economic projects to build up a dense
industrial base. However, despite these major achievements (roads, freeways,
universities, hospitals, factories, housing, metro and tramway systems, etc.),
the Algerian economy has gone through various stages of turbulence.

In the 1980s, the Algerian economy experienced major difficulties. The oil
counter-shock of 1986 dealt a heavy blow to a virtually rentier economy,
during the period of anti-scarcity and stabilization plans. In the early
1990s, Algeria embarked on a series of structural reforms, making the
transition to a market economy a reality.

In 2012, the Algerian economy remains highly dependent on hydrocarbon rents,
which represent the country's main source of revenue, without having succeeded
in diversifying and establishing internationally competitive
industrialization.

The 2017 report on Algeria by business intelligence and consultancy firm
Oxford Business Group (OGB), highlights the efforts devoted by the country to
strengthening and diversifying its economy against the backdrop of falling oil
prices. The report highlights the growing contribution of the private sector
to GDP, in particular the role of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs)
supported by new measures; as well as the financial services sector, which has
seen positive developments such as the introduction of online payments.

Despite the efforts made, the country still faces a number of short-term
problems, including the need to diversify the economy, strengthen political,
economic and financial reforms, improve the business climate and reduce social
inequality between regions, in order to achieve better economic growth.
Algeria has the triple leverage of energy, mining and agriculture to
contribute, in the long term, to containing the supply crises in energy, rare
earths (minerals useful for technology) and food.

Published in 2023, the World Bank's report on the Algerian economy calls for
the acceleration of institutional and micro-economic reforms, and paints a
positive picture for the country's economy. The World Bank notes that the
promulgation in 2022 of the new investment law and the publication of its
implementing regulations, the abolition in 2020 of the 51/49 rule for non-
strategic sectors, and the publication of the new hydrocarbons law in 2019 are
positive steps, but must tackle the ecosystem, including paralyzing
bureaucracy, with greater visibility in socio-economic policy.

Continued implementation of government structural reform programs, creating
greater openness to the private sector, improving the economy’s
competitiveness, and strengthening investment in human capital are all
essential to the flourishing and resilience of the Algerian economy.
openai_summarised_points: • The Wikipedia section on the "Economy of Algeria" introduces the topic by highlighting the need for updates and additional citations, with specific references to issues identified as of January 2021.

• The section notes that the article has multiple issues, including the need for improvement and verification, and encourages contributions on the talk page to enhance content accuracy and completeness.
• It emphasizes that the article requires updating to reflect recent events or newly available information, with a specific call for updates as of January 2021.

• The section mentions that the article lacks sufficient citations from reliable sources, such as news outlets, newspapers, books, scholars, and JSTOR, and urges contributors to add references to improve verifiability.
• It references the "Economy of Algeria" article as a subject of ongoing editing and verification efforts.
• The section provides a visual reference to Algerian exports in 2006, specifically noting the view of the oil port of Béjaïa, indicating the importance of oil exports to the economy.
• It states that the economy of Algeria is characterized as a mixed economy, dealing with both current and structural economic issues.

• Since gaining independence in 1962, Algeria has launched major economic projects aimed at developing a dense industrial base, including infrastructure such as roads, freeways, universities, hospitals, factories, housing, metro, and tramway systems.
• Despite these achievements, the Algerian economy has experienced turbulence, including significant difficulties in the 1980s.
• The 1986 oil counter-shock severely impacted Algeria’s rentier economy, which heavily depended on oil revenues, during a period marked by anti-scarcity and stabilization plans.
• In the early 1990s, Algeria initiated structural reforms to transition towards a market economy, marking a significant shift in economic policy.

• As of 2012, Algeria remained highly dependent on hydrocarbon rents, which constitute the main source of national revenue, with limited success in diversifying the economy or establishing internationally competitive industries.

• The 2017 report by Oxford Business Group (OGB) highlights efforts to diversify and strengthen the economy amid falling oil prices, emphasizing the growing role of the private sector and SMEs supported by new measures.
• The report notes positive developments in the financial sector, including the introduction of online payments, indicating progress in financial modernization.

• Despite these efforts, Algeria faces short-term challenges such as the urgent need to diversify the economy, implement political, economic, and financial reforms, improve the business climate, and reduce social inequalities between regions to foster better economic growth.

• The country has leverage in energy, mining, and agriculture sectors, which are seen as vital for long-term stability in energy supply, rare earth minerals critical for technology, and food security.
• A 2023 World Bank report describes the Algerian economy as positive overall, calling for accelerated institutional and microeconomic reforms.

• The World Bank highlights key recent reforms, including the 2022 new investment law and its regulations, the 2020 abolition of the 51/49 rule for non-strategic sectors, and the 2019 hydrocarbons law, as positive steps toward economic liberalization.
• The report stresses that these reforms must address systemic issues such as bureaucratic paralysis and provide greater socio-economic policy visibility.

• Continued structural reforms are deemed essential, including fostering private sector openness, enhancing economic competitiveness, and investing in human capital to ensure resilience and sustainable growth of the Algerian economy.

text:
The total imports and exports on the eve of the French invasion (in 1830) did
not exceed £175,000. By 1850, the figures had reached £5,000,000; in 1868,
£12,000,000; in 1880, £17,000,000; and in 1890, £20,000,000. From this point
progress was slower and the figures varied considerably year by year. In 1905
the total value of the foreign trade was £24,500,000. About five-sixths of the
trade is with or via France, into which country several Algerian goods have
been admitted duty-free since 1851, and all since 1867. French goods, except
sugar, have been admitted into Algeria without payment of duty since 1835.
After the 1892 increase of the French minimum tariff which applied to Algeria
for the first time, foreign trade greatly diminished.[_citation needed_]

GDP per capita grew 40% in the 1960s, reaching a peak growth of 538% in the
1970s. Growth collapsed to 9.7% in the turbulent 1980s. Failure of timely
reforms by successive governments caused the current GDP per capita to shrink
by 28% in the 1990s.

This is a chart of trend of gross domestic product of Algeria at market prices
estimated by the International Monetary Fund.

Year | Gross Domestic Product
million Algerian dinars | US Dollar Exchange
Algerian dinars | Inflation Index
(2000=100) | Per Capita Income
(as % of USA)
---|---|---|---|---
1980 | 162,500 | 3.83 | 9.30 | 18.51
1985 | 291,600 | 4.77 | 14 | 15.55
1990 | 554,400 | 12.19 | 22 | 10.65
1995 | 2,004,990 | 47.66 | 73 | 5.39
2000 | 4,123,514 | 75.31 | 100 | 5.17
2005 | 7,493,000 | 73.44 | 114 | 7.43

For purchasing power parity comparisons, the US dollar is exchanged at 70.01
Algerian dinars only (updated May 24, 2007). Average wages in 2007 hover
around US$18–22 per day.

East-West Highway near Relizane

Burdened with a heavy foreign debt, Algiers concluded a one-year standby
arrangement with the International Monetary Fund in April 1994 and the
following year signed onto a three-year extended fund facility which ended 30
April 1998. In March 2006, Russia agreed to erase $4.74 billion of Algeria's
Soviet-era debt during a visit by President Vladimir Putin to the country, the
first by a Russian leader in half a century. In return, president Abdelaziz
Bouteflika agreed to buy $7.5 billion worth of combat planes, air-defence
systems and other arms from Russia, according to the head of Russia's state
arms exporter Rosoboronexport.

Some progress on economic reform, Paris Club debt reschedulings in 1995 and
1996, and oil and gas sector expansion contributed to a recovery in growth
since 1995, reducing inflation to approximately 1% and narrowing the budget
deficit. Algeria's economy has grown at about 4% annually since 1999. The
country's foreign debt has fallen from a high of $28 billion in 1999 to its
current level of $5 billion. The spike in oil prices in 1999–2000 and the
government's tight fiscal policy, as well as a large increase in the trade
surplus and the near tripling of foreign exchange reserves has helped the
country's finances. However, an ongoing drought, the after effects of the
floods of 10 November 2001 and an uncertain oil market made prospects for
2002-03 more problematic. The government has pledged to continue its efforts
to diversify the economy by attracting foreign and domestic investment outside
the energy sector.

Hotel Zianides in Tlemcen.

President Bouteflika has announced sweeping economic reforms, which, if
implemented, will significantly restructure the economy. Still, the economy
remains heavily dependent on volatile oil and gas revenues. The government has
continued efforts to diversify the economy by attracting foreign and domestic
investment outside the energy sector, but has had little success in reducing
high unemployment and improving living standards. Other priority areas include
banking reform, improving the investment environment, and reducing government
bureaucracy.

The government has announced plans to sell off state enterprises: sales of a
national cement factory and steel plant have been completed and other
industries are up for offer. In 2001, Algeria signed an Association Agreement
with the European Union. In June 1987, Algeria started accession negotiations
for entry into the World Trade Organization, but negotiations ceased in 2014.

In the 2000s the country enjoyed several years of strong economic performance,
with solid non-hydrocarbon growth, low inflation, an overall budget surplus
and a positive trade balance.
openai_summarised_points: • On the eve of the French invasion in 1830, Algeria's total imports and exports did not exceed £175,000.
• By 1850, the total trade value increased significantly to £5,000,000.
• In 1868, foreign trade reached £12,000,000, and by 1880, it grew further to £17,000,000.
• In 1890, the trade total was £20,000,000, with subsequent growth slowing and fluctuating annually.
• The total foreign trade value in 1905 was approximately £24,500,000.
• About five-sixths of Algeria's foreign trade was conducted with or through France.
• Since 1851, several Algerian goods have been admitted duty-free into France, with all goods admitted duty-free since 1867.
• French goods, except sugar, have been admitted into Algeria without duty since 1835.
• Following the 1892 increase in the French minimum tariff, which applied to Algeria for the first time, foreign trade significantly declined.
• Algeria's GDP per capita grew by 40% during the 1960s.
• The GDP per capita experienced a peak growth of 538% in the 1970s.
• During the 1980s, growth collapsed to 9.7%, amid turbulence.
• In the 1990s, due to government reform failures, GDP per capita shrank by 28%.
• The IMF estimates the trend of Algeria's gross domestic product (GDP) at market prices, with data points as follows:
• 1980: 162,500 million Algerian dinars; USD exchange rate: 3.83; inflation index: 9.30 (2000=100); per capita income: 18.51% of USA.
• 1985: 291,600 million Algerian dinars; USD exchange rate: 4.77; inflation index: 14; per capita income: 15.55%.
• 1990: 554,400 million Algerian dinars; USD exchange rate: 12.19; inflation index: 22; per capita income: 10.65%.
• 1995: 2,004,990 million Algerian dinars; USD exchange rate: 47.66; inflation index: 73; per capita income: 5.39%.
• 2000: 4,123,514 million Algerian dinars; USD exchange rate: 75.31; inflation index: 100; per capita income: 5.17%.
• 2005: 7,493,000 million Algerian dinars; USD exchange rate: 73.44; inflation index: 114; per capita income: 7.43%.
• For purchasing power parity comparisons, the US dollar is exchanged at 70.01 Algerian dinars (as of May 24, 2007).
• Average wages in 2007 ranged around US$18–22 per day.
• In April 1994, Algeria concluded a one-year standby arrangement with the IMF due to heavy foreign debt.
• In 1995, Algeria signed a three-year extended fund facility with the IMF, ending on April 30, 1998.
• In March 2006, Russia agreed to forgive $4.74 billion of Algeria's Soviet-era debt during President Vladimir Putin's visit—the first Russian leader's visit in 50 years.

• In exchange, President Abdelaziz Bouteflika committed to purchasing $7.5 billion worth of military equipment from Russia, including combat planes and air-defense systems, according to Rosoboronexport.
• Economic reforms, Paris Club debt rescheduling in 1995 and 1996, and expansion in the oil and gas sector contributed to economic recovery since 1995.
• Since 1995, inflation was reduced to approximately 1%, and the budget deficit was narrowed.
• Algeria's economy has grown at about 4% annually since 1999.
• The country's foreign debt decreased from a high of $28 billion in 1999 to approximately $5 billion currently.
• The spike in oil prices during 1999–2000, along with tight fiscal policies, increased trade surplus and foreign exchange reserves, bolstered the economy.
• Challenges for 2002–03 included ongoing drought, the aftermath of floods on November 10, 2001, and uncertain oil markets.
• The government pledged to diversify the economy by attracting both foreign and domestic investment outside the energy sector.
• President Bouteflika announced sweeping economic reforms aimed at restructuring the economy, though dependence on volatile oil and gas revenues remains high.
• Efforts to diversify the economy have had limited success in reducing high unemployment and improving living standards.
• Priority areas include banking reform, improving the investment climate, and reducing bureaucratic obstacles.
• The government announced plans to privatize state enterprises, successfully selling a national cement factory and steel plant, with other industries also up for sale.
• In 2001, Algeria signed an Association Agreement with the European Union.
• In June 1987, Algeria began accession negotiations to join the World Trade Organization, but negotiations ceased in 2014.
• During the 2000s, Algeria experienced several years of strong economic performance characterized by solid non-hydrocarbon growth, low inflation, a budget surplus, and a positive trade balance.

text:
In 2023 Algeria's nominal GDP is estimated to be US$224.10 billion. Using
purchasing power parity, estimated GDP was US$628.99 billion, or US$13,680 on
a per capita basis. The estimated real growth rate is 2.6%, down from 3.4% in
2022. In 2017 industry accounted for 39.3%% of GDP, services constituted
47.4%, and agriculture provided the remaining 13.3%.

After having virtually eliminated external debt before 2013, the drop
hydrocarbon prices and revenues has led to a large budget deficit which has
been only partly offset by spending cuts. Consequently, government debt has
increased to more than 30% of GDP. Inflation has remained at 3-6% on average
for 2013–17. However, the economy remains highly dependent on hydrocarbons,
which represent 89% of total exports; a continued slowdown of global energy
demand has significantly put pressure on Algeria's fiscal and external
positions.
openai_summarised_points: • In 2023, Algeria's nominal Gross Domestic Product (GDP) is estimated at US$224.10 billion.
• Using purchasing power parity (PPP), Algeria's estimated GDP is US$628.99 billion, which equates to approximately US$13,680 per capita.
• The estimated real GDP growth rate for 2023 is 2.6%, representing a decline from 3.4% in 2022.
• In 2017, the composition of Algeria's GDP was as follows: industry accounted for 39.3%, services constituted 47.4%, and agriculture contributed 13.3%.
• Prior to 2013, Algeria virtually eliminated its external debt; however, a decline in hydrocarbon prices and revenues led to a significant budget deficit.
• The budget deficit resulting from decreased hydrocarbon revenues has been only partially offset by government spending cuts.
• As a consequence of these fiscal pressures, Algeria's government debt has increased to over 30% of GDP.
• Between 2013 and 2017, inflation in Algeria remained relatively stable, averaging between 3% and 6%.
• The Algerian economy remains highly dependent on hydrocarbons, which constitute 89% of the country's total exports.
• A continued slowdown in global energy demand has exerted considerable pressure on Algeria's fiscal stability and external economic position.

text:
In 2007, government revenues of US$58.5 billion exceeded expenditures of
US$41.4 billion. Receipts from the hydrocarbons industry usually account for
roughly 60% of revenues.
openai_summarised_points: • In 2007, the Algerian government recorded total revenues of US$58.5 billion.
• During the same year, government expenditures amounted to US$41.4 billion.
• Hydrocarbons industry receipts typically constitute approximately 60% of Algeria's total government revenues.

• The table presents key macroeconomic indicators of Algeria from 1980 to 2023, including GDP (both in PPP and nominal terms), GDP per capita, GDP growth rate, inflation rate, unemployment rate, and government debt as a percentage of GDP.
• Inflation rates below 5% are highlighted in green throughout the data set.

• In 1980, Algeria's GDP was 89.7 billion US dollars (PPP), with a GDP per capita of 4,808 US dollars (PPP), and a nominal GDP of 42.3 billion US dollars; the economy experienced a -5.4% real GDP growth and a 9.7% inflation rate; unemployment was 15.8%, with government debt data not available.

• Between 1981 and 1985, GDP steadily increased from 101.2 billion US dollars (PPP) to 149.2 billion US dollars, with GDP per capita rising from 5,257 to 6,722 US dollars (PPP), and inflation fluctuated around 5-6%, with unemployment rates generally increasing, reaching 16.9% in 1985.
• In 1986, GDP growth was nearly stagnant at -0.2%, with inflation rising to 14.0%, and unemployment increasing to 18.4%.
• The late 1980s saw negative or low GDP growth, with 1988 experiencing a -1.9% contraction, inflation remaining below 6%, and unemployment fluctuating around 5.8% to 21.8%.

• The early 1990s marked economic instability: in 1991, GDP was 182.6 billion US dollars (PPP), with a significant unemployment spike to 25.9%, and inflation at 1.2%; government debt was 77.8% of GDP.
• During 1992-1994, GDP growth varied, with 1992 experiencing 1.6% growth, and inflation reaching 31.7% in 1992, while unemployment remained high, exceeding 20%.

• From 1995 onwards, GDP growth generally improved, with notable increases in GDP in nominal terms, reaching 246.8 billion US dollars in 1999 and 262.0 billion US dollars in 2000, with inflation rates decreasing to below 4% by 2000.

• The early 2000s saw consistent GDP growth, with 2003 reaching 323.5 billion US dollars (PPP) and 67.9% inflation, but by 2006, inflation dropped to 1.7%, and GDP in PPP terms was 396.7 billion US dollars.
• From 2007 onwards, GDP continued to grow, reaching 495.4 billion US dollars in 2018, with inflation remaining below 5% in most years, notably 1.2% in 2018 and 1.0% in 2019.
• The COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 caused a GDP contraction of -5.1%, with GDP in PPP terms decreasing to 145.7 billion US dollars and inflation at 2.4%; unemployment was 11.4%.

• Post-pandemic recovery is evident: in 2021, GDP in PPP terms increased to 163.1 billion US dollars, with inflation rising to 7.2%, and in 2022, GDP further increased to 195.1 billion US dollars with inflation at 9.3%.

• By 2023, Algeria's GDP in PPP terms reached 224.1 billion US dollars, with a GDP per capita of 13,682 US dollars, and inflation stabilized at 9.0%, while unemployment was at 9.0%, and government debt was 55.1% of GDP.

text:
Algeria's economy includes a significant public sector built up under a policy
of import substitution industrialization which remained intact after other
developing nations liberalised their economies under the influence of
structural adjustment programmes advocated by the World Bank and the
International Monetary Fund towards the end of the 20th century. As of 2019,
this sector consisted of 400 publicly owned firms, and generates a third of
the state's revenue. Although economic liberalisation has advocates in
Algeria, in 2018 froze all plans to pursue privatisation.

In addition, the social safety net in Algeria is stronger than in other
countries in the region: it saw periods of expansion in the 1970s, and in the
2000s, helping to build stability after the Civil War. It is supplemented by
consumer subsidies. These measures allow for wages to be kept low.

The restrictive political economy in Algeria and continued adherence to the
ISI model has limited foreign direct investment in the country: Algeria has
one of the lowest levels of FDI in Africa. However, local businesses have
benefited from the state undertaking public works projects in the construction
of roads, ports, dams and housing. Both fixed capital formation and credit
extended to the private sector increased during the 2010s.
openai_summarised_points: • Algeria's economy features a substantial public sector that was developed through a policy of import substitution industrialization (ISI), which remained largely unchanged even after other developing countries liberalized their economies under structural adjustment programs promoted by the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) towards the end of the 20th century.
• As of 2019, the public sector comprised approximately 400 publicly owned firms and was responsible for generating about one-third (33.3%) of the Algerian state's revenue.
• Despite the presence of advocates for economic liberalization within Algeria, the government in 2018 halted all plans for privatization, maintaining the dominance of the public sector.

• Algeria's social safety net is comparatively stronger than in other regional countries, having experienced expansion during the 1970s and again in the 2000s, which contributed to national stability following the Civil War.
• The social safety measures are supplemented by consumer subsidies, which help to keep wages low and support household welfare.

• The restrictive political economy and persistent adherence to the ISI model have significantly limited foreign direct investment (FDI) in Algeria, resulting in one of the lowest FDI levels in Africa.
• Nevertheless, local Algerian businesses have benefited from government-led public works projects, including the construction of roads, ports, dams, and housing developments.
• During the 2010s, both fixed capital formation and credit extended to the private sector increased, indicating some growth in private sector activity despite overall FDI restrictions.

• Algeria's agricultural sector contributes approximately 8 percent to the country's gross domestic product (GDP) but employs about 14 percent of the workforce, indicating a relatively low productivity per worker in agriculture.
• The sector is unable to fully meet the food needs of the Algerian population, resulting in approximately 45 percent of food being imported to supplement domestic production.
• The primary crops cultivated in Algeria include wheat, barley, and potatoes, which form the backbone of the country's agricultural output.
• Farmers have achieved notable success in cultivating dates for export purposes, contributing to Algeria's agricultural exports.
• Agricultural cultivation is predominantly concentrated in the fertile coastal plain of the Tell region, which constitutes only a small portion of Algeria's total territory.
• Overall, only about 3 percent of Algeria's land area is classified as arable land, reflecting limited agricultural land availability.
• Even within the Tell region, rainfall variability significantly impacts agricultural productivity, posing challenges to consistent crop yields.

• Government initiatives aimed at stimulating farming in the less arable steppe and desert regions have met with limited success, highlighting the difficulties of expanding agriculture into less fertile areas.
• Livestock herders maintain cattle and sheep primarily in the High Plateaus region, supporting pastoral activities despite environmental constraints.
• Algeria's climate and periodic wildfires hinder the development of a robust forestry industry; however, the country produces cork and Aleppo pine.
• In 2005, roundwood removals totaled 7.8 million cubic meters, indicating forestry activity levels, while sawnwood production was relatively low at 13 million cubic meters annually.
• In 2018, Algeria's agricultural production included:
• 4.6 million tonnes of potatoes, making it the 17th largest global producer.
• 3.9 million tonnes of wheat.
• 2 million tonnes of watermelon, ranking 6th worldwide.
• 1.9 million tonnes of barley, ranking 18th globally.
• 1.4 million tonnes of onions, ranking 16th in the world.
• 1.3 million tonnes of tomatoes, also ranking 18th globally.
• 1.1 million tonnes of oranges, ranking 14th worldwide.
• 1 million tonnes of dates, making Algeria the 4th largest producer globally, behind Egypt, Saudi Arabia, and Iran.
• 860 thousand tonnes of olives, ranking 6th in the world.
• 651 thousand tonnes of peppers.
• 502 thousand tonnes of grapes.
• 431 thousand tonnes of carrots.
• 388 thousand tonnes of pumpkins.
• 262 thousand tonnes of tangerines.
• 242 thousand tonnes of apricots, ranking 4th globally, behind Turkey, Iran, and Uzbekistan.
• 207 thousand tonnes of cauliflower and broccoli.
• 202 thousand tonnes of garlic.
• 200 thousand tonnes of pears.
• 193 thousand tonnes of cucumbers.
• 190 thousand tonnes of peaches.
• 186 thousand tonnes of peas.
• 181 thousand tonnes of aubergines.
• 124 thousand tonnes of artichokes, ranking 5th worldwide, after Italy, Egypt, Spain, and Peru.
• 118 thousand tonnes of oats.
• 111 thousand tonnes of plums, ranking 20th globally.
• 109 thousand tonnes of figs, ranking 4th worldwide, behind Turkey, Egypt, and Morocco.
• Algeria also produces smaller quantities of various other agricultural products, contributing to its diverse agricultural profile.

text:
Algeria's fishing industry does not take full advantage of the Mediterranean
coast, in part because fishing is generally done from small family-owned boats
instead of large commercial fishing trawlers. However, the government is
attempting to boost the relatively small catch—slightly more than 125,000
metric tons in 2005—by modernizing fishing ports, permitting foreigners to
fish in Algerian waters, and subsidizing fishing-related projects.

Fishing is a flourishing but minor industry. Fish caught are principally
sardines, bonito, mackerel, smelt and sprats. Fresh fish are exported to
France, dried and preserved fish to Spain and Italy. Coral fisheries are found
along the coast from Bona to Tunis. The annual catch averages around 142,000
tons, 54% sardines.
openai_summarised_points: • Algeria's fishing industry underutilizes its Mediterranean coast, largely due to reliance on small, family-owned boats rather than large commercial fishing trawlers.
• In 2005, the total fish catch was slightly more than 125,000 metric tons.

• The Algerian government is actively working to increase the fishing industry’s productivity by modernizing fishing ports, allowing foreign fishing vessels to operate in Algerian waters, and subsidizing various fishing-related projects.
• Despite being a relatively small industry, fishing is considered flourishing within its scale.
• The primary fish species caught include sardines, bonito, mackerel, smelt, and sprats.
• Export markets for Algerian fish include France for fresh fish, while dried and preserved fish are exported to Spain and Italy.
• Coral fisheries are present along the coast from Bona to Tunis.
• The annual total catch averages approximately 142,000 tons, with sardines accounting for 54% of this catch.

text:
Algeria is rich in minerals; the country has many iron, lead, zinc, copper,
calamine, antimony and mercury mines. The most productive are those of iron
and zinc. Lignite is found in Algiers; immense phosphate beds were discovered
near Tébessa in 1891, yielding 313,500 tons in 1905. Phosphate beds are also
worked near Sétif, Guelma and Aïn Beïda. There are more than 300 quarries
which produce, amongst other stones, onyx and white and red marbles. Algerian
onyx from Ain Tekbalet was used by the Romans, and many ancient quarries have
been found near Sidi Ben Yebka, some being certainly those from which the
long-lost Numidian marbles were taken. Salt is collected on the margins of the
chotts.

In 2019, the country was the 17th largest world producer of gypsum, and the
19th largest world producer of phosphate.
openai_summarised_points: • Algeria is rich in mineral resources, possessing numerous mines for iron, lead, zinc, copper, calamine, antimony, and mercury.
• The most productive mineral mines in Algeria are those of iron and zinc.
• Lignite deposits are found in Algiers.
• Immense phosphate beds were discovered near Tébessa in 1891, which yielded 313,500 tons of phosphate in 1905.
• Additional phosphate beds are exploited near Sétif, Guelma, and Aïn Beïda.
• Algeria has over 300 quarries producing various stones, including onyx and white and red marbles.
• Algerian onyx from Ain Tekbalet was historically used by the Romans.
• Many ancient quarries have been discovered near Sidi Ben Yebka, some of which are believed to be the sources of the long-lost Numidian marbles.
• Salt is harvested along the margins of the chotts (salt lakes).
• In 2019, Algeria ranked as the 17th largest producer of gypsum globally.
• In the same year, Algeria was the 19th largest producer of phosphate worldwide.

text:
Algeria's banking sector is dominated by public banks, which suffer from high
levels of non-performing loans to state-owned enterprises (SOEs). As of 2007,
public banks controlled 95 percent of total bank assets. In 2007 nonperforming
loans represented a towering 38 percent of total loans at public banks,
according to International Monetary Fund (IMF) estimates. Modest progress has
been made in implementing several reforms proposed by the IMF, including
replacing bank credits to SOEs with government subsidies; boosting bank
supervision, accountability, and transparency; and modernizing the payments
system. One specific reform that has been achieved is the establishment in
2006 of the Algerian Real Time Settlements system, which facilitates the
prompt and reliable electronic transfer of payments. In November 2007, the
proposed sale and privatization of Crédit Populaire d’Algérie was postponed
because of turbulent market conditions. Recently, HSBC and Deutsche Bank
announced that they would commence commercial banking (in the case of HSBC)
and investment banking (in the case of Deutsche Bank) in Algeria. Only a few
companies are listed on the underdeveloped and relatively opaque Algiers stock
exchange. The non-bank sector remains less developed, although recent reforms
in the field of regulation and supervision have laid the foundations for
leasing, factoring, and venture capital.

The Algerian equity market remains relatively shallow, with only four
companies being listed in the Bourse d’Algerie. Conversely, the bond market
has expanded in recent years: the government has issued debt instruments with
varying maturities of up to fifteen years, and five private companies have
issued corporate bonds.

The insurance sector was liberalized in 1995, but is still dominated by
government-owned institutions and so far accounts only for a very small part
of the economy: total premium volume amounted to approximately 1 percent of
GDP. The pension sector encompasses three pension funds, which attained
coverage of approximately 40 percent of the working population in 2005.

Based on 2006 and 2007 estimates, 31 percent of the total population has
access to financial services, with one bank branch or post office every 7,250
inhabitants. The microfinance sector still has great potential for further
development. A 2006 study could not find major regulatory impediments to
microfinance and suggested that the geographical net of postal offices –
offering an increasing number of financial services to customers – holds a
high potential of increasing access to finance for the Algerian population.

Official remittance inflows increased steadily from US$1.9 to 2.9 billion
between 2005 and 2007.
openai_summarised_points: • Algeria's banking sector is predominantly composed of public banks, which face significant challenges due to high levels of non-performing loans, particularly to state-owned enterprises (SOEs).
• As of 2007, public banks controlled approximately 95 percent of the total banking assets in Algeria.
• In 2007, non-performing loans at public banks accounted for about 38 percent of total loans, according to estimates by the International Monetary Fund (IMF).

• The government has made modest progress in implementing reforms recommended by the IMF, including replacing bank credits to SOEs with government subsidies, enhancing bank supervision, increasing accountability and transparency, and modernizing the payments system.
• A notable reform achieved is the establishment of the Algerian Real Time Settlements system in 2006, which enables prompt and reliable electronic transfer of payments.
• In November 2007, the proposed sale and privatization of Crédit Populaire d’Algérie was postponed due to turbulent market conditions.
• Recently, HSBC announced plans to commence commercial banking operations in Algeria, while Deutsche Bank indicated intentions to start investment banking activities within the country.
• The Algerian stock exchange, the Bourse d’Algerie, remains underdeveloped and relatively opaque, with only a few companies listed.

• The non-bank financial sector is less developed; however, recent regulatory and supervisory reforms have laid the groundwork for the development of leasing, factoring, and venture capital activities.
• The equity market in Algeria is shallow, with only four companies listed on the Bourse d’Algerie.

• Conversely, the bond market has experienced growth in recent years, with the government issuing debt instruments with maturities up to fifteen years, and five private companies issuing corporate bonds.
• The insurance sector was liberalized in 1995 but remains dominated by government-owned institutions, contributing only about 1 percent of GDP in total premiums.
• The pension sector comprises three pension funds, which covered approximately 40 percent of the working population as of 2005.
• Based on estimates from 2006 and 2007, approximately 31 percent of the Algerian population has access to financial services, with one bank branch or post office serving every 7,250 inhabitants.

• The microfinance sector holds significant potential for further development; a 2006 study found no major regulatory barriers and highlighted the extensive network of postal offices offering increasing financial services as a key factor for expanding access.
• Official remittance inflows into Algeria increased steadily from US$1.9 billion in 2005 to US$2.9 billion in 2007.

text:
Algeria's tourism industry, which contributes only about 1 percent of GDP,
lags behind that of its neighbors Morocco and Tunisia. Algeria receives only
about 200,000 tourists and visitors annually. Ethnic Algerian French citizens
represent the largest group of tourists, followed by Tunisians. The modest
level of tourism is attributable to a combination of poor hotel accommodations
and the threat of terrorism. However, the government has adopted a plan known
as “Horizon 2025,” which is designed to address these shortcomings. Various
hotel operators are planning to build hotels, particularly along the
Mediterranean coast. Another opportunity involves adventure holidays in the
Sahara (which comprises approximately 80% of the country's land area). In
addition to potential ecotourism, the country boasts many cultural and
historical sites, seven of which are UNESCO World Heritage Sites. The Algerian
government set the goal of boosting the number of foreign visitors, including
tourists, to 10 million by 2030.
openai_summarised_points: • Algeria's tourism industry contributes approximately 1 percent to the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• The tourism sector in Algeria significantly lags behind that of neighboring countries Morocco and Tunisia in terms of development and scale.
• Annually, Algeria receives only about 200,000 tourists and visitors.
• The largest group of tourists visiting Algeria are ethnic Algerian French citizens, followed by tourists from Tunisia.
• The modest level of tourism in Algeria is primarily due to poor hotel accommodations and the ongoing threat of terrorism.
• The Algerian government has implemented a strategic plan called “Horizon 2025” aimed at addressing the shortcomings in the tourism sector.
• Under the Horizon 2025 plan, various hotel operators are planning to construct new hotels, especially along the Mediterranean coast.
• An emerging opportunity for tourism development involves adventure holidays in the Sahara Desert, which accounts for approximately 80% of Algeria’s land area.
• The country offers potential for ecotourism, leveraging its natural landscapes and biodiversity.
• Algeria possesses numerous cultural and historical sites, including seven designated UNESCO World Heritage Sites.
• The Algerian government has set an ambitious goal to increase the number of foreign visitors, including tourists, to 10 million by the year 2030.

text:
Algeria has many diversified industries that contribute to meet local demands
and some times to exportation. The food industry is one of the largest
industrial sector in Algeria. Private companies generally dominate the food
sector in Algeria with large companies such as Cevital, La Belle, Groupe Bimo,
Hamoud Boualam, Ifri, Général Emballage.

The pharmaceutical industry is also present in Algeria, with the domination of
state-owned company Saidal, as well as other small private companies. The
local pharmaceutical industry covers 38% of local needs.

The mechanical industry has existed in Algeria for a long time, with the
state-owned company SNVI (Société Nationale des Véhicules Industriels) being
the largest producer of buses and industrial vehicles in the region. These
vehicles are exported to the Maghreb, Africa, and the Middle East. Mercedes-
Benz has also invested in Algeria in cooperation with a state-owned company to
produce industrial and military vehicles. Deutz AG also invested to produce
agricultural utilities.

In the electric and electronic industry, Algeria has made a great leap in the
field compared to its neighbours. The Algerian region Bordj-Bou-Arreridj is
the biggest electronic pole in Africa, local companies cover 83% of it needs
and export other products, Algeria started producing some 100% home made
electronic product including smartphones, tablets, TV, TV decoders, air
conditioning products ..., at least 16 big companies are active in the field,
some of the companies are : Bya Electronic, HB Technologies, ZALA Computer,
Cristor, Condor, Cobra, Continental électronique, Essalem Electronics, Samha,
FRIGOR, BMS Electric, Bomare Company, etc.

In December 2023 Italian carmaker Fiat has announced that it has opened its
first manufacturing plant in Tafraoui, Algeria.
openai_summarised_points: • Algeria possesses a diversified industrial sector that fulfills domestic demands and occasionally contributes to exports.
• The food industry is among the largest industrial sectors in Algeria, with private companies predominantly leading the market.
• Major private companies in the food sector include Cevital, La Belle, Groupe Bimo, Hamoud Boualam, Ifri, and Général Emballage.
• The pharmaceutical industry in Algeria is primarily dominated by the state-owned company Saidal, alongside several smaller private firms.
• The local pharmaceutical industry currently satisfies approximately 38% of Algeria’s domestic pharmaceutical needs.
• Algeria’s mechanical industry has a longstanding history, with SNVI (Société Nationale des Véhicules Industriels) being the largest producer of buses and industrial vehicles in the region.
• SNVI exports its vehicles to the Maghreb, Africa, and the Middle East.
• Mercedes-Benz has invested in Algeria through a partnership with a state-owned company to produce industrial and military vehicles.
• Deutz AG has also invested in Algeria to manufacture agricultural utilities.
• The electric and electronic industry in Algeria has advanced significantly compared to neighboring countries.
• The Bordj-Bou-Arreridj region is the largest electronic hub in Africa, with local companies fulfilling 83% of its electronic needs and exporting additional products.
• Algeria has begun producing fully domestically manufactured electronic products, including smartphones, tablets, TVs, TV decoders, and air conditioning units.

• Approximately 16 major companies operate in Algeria’s electronics sector, such as Bya Electronic, HB Technologies, ZALA Computer, Cristor, Condor, Cobra, Continental électronique, Essalem Electronics, Samha, FRIGOR, BMS Electric, and Bomare Company.
• In December 2023, Italian car manufacturer Fiat announced the opening of its first manufacturing plant in Tafraoui, Algeria.

text:
Algeria's currency is the Algerian dinar (DZD). The dinar is loosely linked to
the U.S. dollar in a managed float. Algeria's main export, crude oil, is
priced in dollars, while most of Algeria's imports are priced in euros.
Therefore, the government endeavors to manage fluctuations in the value of the
dinar. As of April 2008, US$1 was equivalent to about DZD 64.6.

Algeria's foreign currency reserves have grown rapidly since 2000, reflecting
rising prices for exported oil. At the end of 2007, foreign reserves totaled
US$99.3 billion, up from US$12 billion in 2000 and the equivalent of almost
four years of imports. In 2007 the estimated inflation rate was 4.6 percent.

In 2010, the IMF voiced concerns about poor management of Algeria's monetary
system and inflation.

In April 2014, a report focusing on world economic projections was published
by the IMF, according to which it was predicted that, in 2015, Algeria's
economic growth would fall by 1.5%, while unemployment would rise by 1.2%.
openai_summarised_points: • Algeria's official currency is the Algerian dinar, abbreviated as DZD.
• The dinar is loosely linked to the U.S. dollar through a managed float exchange rate system.
• Algeria's main export commodity is crude oil, which is priced in U.S. dollars.
• Most of Algeria's imports are priced in euros.
• The government actively manages fluctuations in the value of the dinar due to its currency composition and trade practices.
• As of April 2008, the exchange rate was approximately US$1 = DZD 64.6.
• Algeria's foreign currency reserves have experienced rapid growth since 2000, primarily driven by rising oil export prices.
• At the end of 2007, Algeria's foreign reserves totaled US$99.3 billion, representing nearly four years' worth of imports.
• In 2000, foreign reserves were approximately US$12 billion, indicating significant growth over the period.
• The estimated inflation rate in Algeria for 2007 was 4.6 percent.
• In 2010, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) expressed concerns regarding poor management of Algeria's monetary system and inflation control.
• A 2014 IMF report on global economic projections predicted that in 2015, Algeria's economic growth would decline by 1.5%.
• The same report forecasted that unemployment in Algeria would increase by 1.2% in 2015.

text:
The largest employer is government, which claims 32 percent of the workforce.
Even though industry is a much larger part of the economy than agriculture,
agriculture employs slightly more people (14 percent of the workforce) than
industry (13.4 percent of the workforce). One of the reasons for this
disparity is that the energy sector is very capital-intensive. Trade accounts
for 14.6 percent of the workforce, while the construction and public works
sector employs 10 percent, reflecting the government's efforts to upgrade the
country's infrastructure and stock of affordable housing.

Unemployment has remained at levels around 10% since 2010 but is significantly
higher for youth (24.8%) and women (16.3%)

At the end of 2006, the unemployment rate was about 15.7 percent, but the rate
among those under the age of 25 was 70 percent. In 2005 the labor
participation rate was only 52 percent, versus an Organisation for Economic
Co-operation and Development average of 70 percent. New entrants to the
workforce and the lack of emigration options make unemployment a chronic
problem and an important challenge to the government. Given its highly
capital-intensive nature, the hydrocarbons industry is not in a position to
employ many job seekers.

Algeria is seeking more trade and foreign investment. For example, the
hydrocarbons law passed in April 2005 is designed to encourage foreign
investment in energy exploration. Increased production could raise Algeria's
profile as a member of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries.
In keeping with its pro-trade agenda, Algeria achieved association status with
the European Union (EU) in September 2005. Over a 12-year period, the
association agreement is expected to enable Algeria to export goods to the EU
tariff-free, while it gradually lifts tariffs on imports from the EU. Algeria
has signed bilateral investment agreements with 20 different nations,
including many European countries, China, Egypt, Malaysia, and Yemen. In July
2001, the United States and Algeria agreed on a framework for discussions
leading to such an agreement, but a final treaty has not yet been negotiated.
Ultimately, trade liberalization, customs modernization, deregulation, and
banking reform are designed to improve the country's negotiating position as
it seeks accession to the World Trade Organization.

In 2007 Algerian imports totaled US$26.08 billion. The principal imports were
capital goods, foodstuffs, and consumer goods. The top import partners were
France (22 percent), Italy (8.6 percent), China (8.5 percent), Germany (5.9
percent), Spain (5.9 percent), the United States (4.8 percent), and Turkey
(4.5 percent). In 2007 Algeria exported US$63.3 billion, more than twice as
much as it imported. Exports accounted for 30 percent of gross domestic
product (GDP). Hydrocarbon products constituted at least 95 percent of export
earnings. The principal exports were petroleum, natural gas, and petroleum
products. The top export partners were the United States (27.2 percent), Italy
(17 percent), Spain (9.7 percent), France (8.8 percent), Canada (8.1 percent),
and Belgium (4.3 percent). Algeria supplies 25 percent of the European Union's
natural gas imports. In 2007 Algeria posted a positive merchandise trade
balance of US$37.2 billion. In 2007 Algeria achieved a positive current
account balance of US$31.5 billion. High prices for Algeria's energy exports
are the main driver for the improvement in the current account balance.

Algeria's trade surplus for 2010 rose to over $83.14 billion. The Algerian
Centre for Information and Statistics Directorate of the Algerian Customs
attribute this increase from the previous year to higher fuel revenue due to
higher prices for a barrel of oil, and a slight decrease in imports of
consumer non-food materials. The center said that Algerian exports rose by
78.26% during the period from January to November 2010 from $27.51 billion to
$44.4 billion during the same period in 2009. Imports grew by 89.1% from
$43.36 billion to $76.35 billion between 2009 and 2010.

Reflecting strong oil export revenues, external debt is on a downward
trajectory. For example, these revenues facilitated early repayments of US$900
million in loans from the African Development Bank and Saudi Arabia. In March
2006, Algeria's purchase of 78 aircraft from Russia led to the cancellation of
Algeria's entire debt to Russia. In 2006 external debt was estimated at US$4.4
billion, down from US$23.5 billion in 2003.

In 2006 foreign direct investment (FDI) in Algeria totaled US$1.8 billion. The
petrochemical, transport, and utilities sectors have been recent beneficiaries
of FDI. FDI into the oil sector was expected to rise as a result of a
hydrocarbons law, approved in April 2005, that created a more even playing
field for foreign oil companies to compete with Algeria's state-owned oil
company, Sonatrach, for exploration and production contracts. Algeria also is
seeking foreign investment in power and water systems.

As of August 2006, cumulative World Bank assistance to Algeria totaled US$5.9
billion, encompassing 72 projects. Currently, the World Bank is pursuing seven
projects, specifically budget modernization, mortgage finance, natural
disaster recovery, energy and mining, rural employment, telecommunications,
and transportation. In 2005 economic assistance to Algeria from the United
States amounted to US$4.4 million, most of which was attributable to the
Middle East Partnership Initiative (MEPI) and the remainder to International
Military Education and Training (IMET). MEPI encourages economic, political,
and educational reform in the Middle East. In 2006 IMET, which provides U.S.
military training to foreign troops, had a budget of US$823 million. In 2005
the European Union contributed US$58 million to Algeria's economic development
under the Euro-Mediterranean Partnership.
